Title:
Colletotrichum siamense is the main etiological agent of
anthracnose of avocado in southeastern Brazil
Keywords:
Infectious process, Post-harvest disease, Multilocus
phylogeny, Pathogenicity, Persea americana
Abstract:
The anthracnose caused by species of Colletotrichum is
considered one of the main post-harvest diseases for avocado. In this
study, Colletotrichum strains associated with avocado anthracnose
collected in different states from Brazil were evaluated through
phylogenetic analysis, morphological characterization and pathogenicity
assays. Moreover, the events during pathogen infection of avocados were
examined by scanning electron microscope. To access genetic diversity of
54 Colletotrichum strains was performed partial sequence analysis of the
gene gapdh. A subset of 14 strains was selected based on the generated
groupings and the geographical origin for performing multilocus
phylogeny analysis (gapdh, act, tub2 and ApMat). Two species previously
described were identified: C. siamense belonging to the C.
gloeosporioides species complex and Colletotrichum karstii belonging to
the C. boninensespecies complex. All Colletotrichum strains evaluated
caused typical symptoms of anthracnose in avocado fruits. The most
virulent strain showed germination of the its conidia occurred between 6
and 12 hai. Penetration through wounds occurred 48 hai, tissue
colonization occurred between 144 and 240 hai, and sporulation at 240
hai via the production of acervulus, conidiophores and conidia. The
findings shed light on the aetiology of avocado anthracnose in Brazil
and provide a better understanding of infection process of this
pathogen, which may assist in the development of disease management
strategies.
